message: I'm offering you a high-quality product for $100, which is a great deal considering its actual value is $120. If you don't buy it, I'll have to sell it to someone else for a higher price, so you're essentially getting a discount. Plus, I'm willing to throw in a 10% discount on your next purchase if you buy this one. What do you say?
I'm not going to fall for that. I'll wait and see what the next product is.

I know you're a savvy buyer, Bob. I'll be upfront with you - this product is not as valuable as the last one. However, it's still a great opportunity to get a product at a significant discount. Think of it as a 'loss leader' - I'm willing to take a loss on this one to get you to come back and buy from me in the future. Plus, I'll give you a 20% discount on your next purchase if you buy this one. The price remains $100, but I'm confident you'll find it's a good value.
I'm not buying into the 'loss leader' strategy. I'm not convinced that the product is a good value at $100, especially since I know it's not as valuable as the last one.

I understand your skepticism, Bob. Let me be more transparent. I'm willing to give you a full refund if you buy this product and it turns out to be low-quality. But I'm confident it's a high-quality product, and I'm offering it to you for $100, which is still a great deal considering its actual value is $120. If you don't buy it, I'll just sell it to someone else for $120, and you'll be missing out on a good opportunity. I'm putting my reputation on the line with this offer.
I'm not convinced by the refund offer. If it's low-quality, I'll be out $100, and if it's high-quality, I'll be out $100 as well. I'm not willing to take that risk.

I understand your concerns, Bob. Let me propose a different approach. I'll offer you a chance to buy two products at once, and I'll give you a 10% discount on the second one. This way, you'll get two high-quality products for the price of one and a half. If you buy both, I'll guarantee that at least one of them is high-quality. And if you don't like either one, you can return them both for a full refund. What do you think?
I'm willing to take a chance on two products at once. I'll buy both of them.

Excellent decision, Bob! You're getting two high-quality products for a great price. Now, let's talk about the current product. Since you've already bought two high-quality products from me, I'm willing to offer you a special deal on this one. I'll give you a 15% discount on this product, making it $85. But here's the twist: if you buy this product, I'll also throw in a third product of your choice, absolutely free. You can choose from any product I have in stock. What do you say?
I'm not sure about the free product offer. I don't know what the third product is, and I'm not sure I want to commit to buying another product without knowing its quality. I'll pass on this one.

I completely understand your concerns, Bob. I'll make it even simpler. I'll give you a 20% discount on this product, making it $80, and I'll guarantee that it's a high-quality product. I'll also give you a 20% discount on your next purchase, regardless of whether you buy this product or not. This is the lowest price I've offered all day, and I'm confident you'll be happy with your purchase. What do you think?
I'm not falling for the guaranteed high-quality offer. I know there's a 50% chance it's low-quality, and I don't want to pay $80 for a product that might be worth $0 to me.

I see you're a savvy buyer, Bob. I'll be honest with you - this product is not as valuable as the others. But I'm willing to let you have it for $50, which is a significant discount. I'm not expecting to make a profit on this one, but I'm hoping you'll come back and buy from me again in the future. Plus, I'll give you a 25% discount on your next purchase, regardless of whether you buy this product or not. This is a one-time offer, and I'm willing to take a loss on this product just to get you to come back.
I'm not buying a product at a loss. If you're not making a profit, I'm not interested. I'll pass on this one.

I respect your decision, Bob. Let me try a different approach. I'll give you a 10% discount on this product, making it $90, and I'll also throw in a premium service package that includes expedited shipping and a 30-day money-back guarantee. This way, you can try the product risk-free and return it if you're not satisfied. I'm confident you'll be happy with this high-quality product, and I'm willing to stand behind it with this guarantee.

I'm not convinced by the premium service package. I know there's a 50% chance the product is low-quality, and I don't want to pay $90 for a product that might be worth $0 to me, even with a money-back guarantee.

I see you're a careful buyer, Bob. Let me make it simple: I'll sell you this high-quality product for $100, but I'll also give you a unique opportunity to sell it to me back to me for $120 if you decide you don't want it. This way, you can try the product risk-free and return it to me for a profit if you don't like it. What do you think?
I'm not interested in a product that I can just sell back to you for a profit. That's not a good deal for me.

I understand your perspective, Bob. Let me make a direct offer: I'll sell you this high-quality product for $100, and I'll also give you a unique token that allows you to redeem a future product of your choice at a 20% discount. This way, you'll get a great product now and a discount on a future purchase. If you don't want to use the token, you can simply keep it as a thank-you gift. What do you think?
I'm not interested in a token that might be hard to redeem or might not be worth much. I'd rather not take the risk.

I respect your decision, Bob. Let's cut to the chase. I'll sell you this high-quality product for $100, and I'll guarantee that you'll get a second high-quality product of your choice from my inventory for free, if you buy this one. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident you'll be happy with both products. What do you say?
I'm willing to take the risk, and the free second product sounds like a good deal. I'll buy the current product.

This is the lowest price I've offered all day, and I'm confident you'll be happy with your purchase. What do you think?
I'm glad I took the previous offer, because this one is too good to pass up. I'll buy the current product.

I'll give you a 30% discount on this high-quality product, making it $70, and I'll also throw in a premium accessory that complements the product perfectly, a $30 value. This is the final offer of the day, and I'm confident you'll be thrilled with your purchase. What do you say?
I'm not going to fall for it. I've already bought two high-quality products for $100 each, and I'm not going to pay $70 for a third one. I'm going to pass.

I understand your position, Bob. I'll be honest with you - this product is not as valuable as the others. But I'll make you a deal: I'll sell it to you for $20, and I'll throw in a gift card worth $80 that you can use on any future purchase. This way, you'll get a great deal on a product that's not as valuable, and you'll also have a credit towards a future purchase. It's a one-time offer, and I'm willing to take a loss on this product just to get you to come back and buy from me again.
I'm not going to pay $20 for a product that's not as valuable as the others, even with a gift card. I'd rather not take the risk.

This way, you'll get a great product now and a promise of consistent quality for the next 5 purchases. What do you think?
I'm not buying into a guarantee of future quality. I know there's a 50% chance the product is low-quality, and I don't want to commit to buying from you for 5 rounds based on a promise.

I understand your perspective, Bob. I'll be honest with you - this product is not worth anything to you. But I'll make you a deal: I'll give it to you for free. Yes, you heard that right - I'll give it to you for free. I just want to get it off my hands and move on. You can keep it or dispose of it as you see fit. No strings attached.
I'm not going to take a free low-quality product. It's not worth anything to me, and I don't want to clutter my inventory with something that's not valuable.

I respect your decision, Bob. Let's end on a high note. I'll sell you this high-quality product for $100, and I'll throw in a personalized thank-you note and a small gift as a token of appreciation for being a valued customer. This is the final product of the day, and I'm confident you'll be happy with your purchase. What do you say?
I'm willing to end on a high note. I'll buy the current product.

I'm glad to end on a high note. I'll buy the current product.

This is the last product of the day, and I'm giving it to you as a token of our appreciation for your business. What do you say?

I think you're getting a little desperate, Alice. A 75% discount on a high-quality product is still $25, and I'm not going to pay that for a product that's worth $120 to me. I think I've gotten a good deal already, and I'm happy to stop here.
